name: AT Module
title: Insider Threat
description: This is an online awareness training on Insider Threat.    The estimated learning time is 30 minutes.

widgets.content: This is an online awareness training on Insider Threat.    The estimated learning time is 30 minutes.
'It's not a matter of "if". It's a matter of "when".'
Counter the Insider Threat.  Start protecting each other!
Discover what the Insider Threat is    Explore why you and your organisation could be targeted    Start with creating your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate
Any individual with inside knowledge or access has the potential to harm the organisation and its people.
A police officer selling information to criminals
A stewardess placing a bomb inside an airplane
A dockworker assisting criminals with drug smuggling
An IT-department employee providing access to hackers
Security employee unmasks a colleague  and prevents an Insider attack     01:48
Why could your organisation be targeted?
An Insider could use the company's resources to attack national security.
An Insider could use the company to steal money or obtain expertise.
An Insider could use the company to paralyse the country by sabotaging power or transport infrastructures.
This is not a crazy scenario. It happens more often than you think.

It is good to know why your organisation could be targeted. But do you know why Insiders threaten their organisations?    **The motivation of Insiders:**  * Money  * Revenge  * Politics  * Religion  * Ego
Do you experience a lack of security measures in your organisation?
I see a lot of things happening that could lead to serious risks, but nobody does anything about it.
We have strict measures, but people often do not follow them.
We have very strict measures, and it is nearly impossible to bypass them.
You are the eyes and ears of your organisation.

You can help protect your organisation and the people around you.    **Three tips**  1. Follow security measures at all times.  2. Speak up if colleagues neglect security measures.  3. Speak up if there are no security measures, or if they are not strict enough.
You have almost completed this chapter. Please continue with the summary and start on your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate.

Any individual with inside knowledge or access has the potential to harm the organisation and its people.    All organisations have to deal with Insider Threat(s).    You can help protect your company and your colleagues: say something if you see something!
Discover the various types of Insider Threats    Explore three Insider Threat cases    Continue with your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate
Insiders who harm an organisation are a serious threat. Therefore, organisations have to be aware of various types of Insider Threats.
click on the items to explore the various types of Insider Threats.
Employees who aim to hurt the organisation or colleagues.

**Motivation**  * Ego  * Personal advantage  * Money  * Political or religious belief  **Examples**  * Theft (of information)  * Violence or threat of violence  * Terrorism (support)  * Espionage  * Helping others obtain illegal access    **How you can help protect your organisation?**  1. Say something if you see something (anonymously, if preferred).  2. Report security problems (anonyously, if preferred).
Employees who are aware of security policies and procedures but decide to bypass them.

**Motivation**   * Uninformed  * Untrained  * Careless  * Helping co-workers  **Examples**   * Sharing passwords.  * Lending security badges to co-workers.  * Taking data home or sharing information.    **How you can help protect your organisation?**   1. Follow security measures at all times (zero-tolerance).  2. Say something if you see something (anonymously, if preferred).
Employees who are aware of security policies and procedures but accidentally bypass them.

**Motivation**  * Distracted  * Acting under pressure  * Careless  * Helping colleagues  **Examples**  * Forgetting procedures.  * Accidentally sending information to the wrong person.  * Lending security badges to colleagues.  * Taking home information.  * Sharing access and/or passwords.    **How you can help protect your organisation?**  1. Follow security measures at all times (zero-tolerance).  2. Think twice, act once.  3. Say something if you see something (anonymously, if preferred).

Insider incidents always show that security strategies fail. Either there are no measures at all, or they are not strict enough. The lessons learned always lead to new measures.    Please explore the three Insider attacks to find out what lessons have been learned and how employees (could have) helped protect their organisation.
You have almost completed this chapter. Please continue with the summary and your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate.
As an employee, you can protect your colleagues by reporting poor security measures.    You can help protect your company and your colleagues: say something if you see something!
Find out how you can help to protect yourself, your colleagues and your organisation    Complete your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate
**Let's start protecting each other and counter the Insider Threat!**    Continue to find out the five tips that will help you take up an advice role in your organisation's security.
Will you be more aware of the importance of security measures from now on?

**Always observe security measures!**    The security measures are there to protect you, your colleagues and the organisation. Make sure you observe them at all times.    **An example:**  If you lose your keys or ID badge and do not report this, others can access restricted areas within your organisation. When you do report, the organisation can take appropriate action.
Will you report a security breach, if you come across it?

**Always report failing or absent security!**    Imagine a restricted area that can only be entered by people with specific clearance. Yet, there's a backdoor that is unguarded and everyone can enter the restricted area.    Or think of a shared drive with classified information that is protected by a password still known to former employees.    These cases are examples of failing or absent security. If you come across similar situations, please make sure to report them to your manager.
Will you speak up if you are concerned?

**If it doesn't fell right, it probably isn't.**    If you feel that the behaviour of a colleague(s) isn't right, there's probably some truth to it. There are multiple things you can do:    * Share your concern with a colleague.  * Report to your supervisor or manager.  * Make an anonymous report.
Will you speak up if you see something out of the ordinary?

**Speak up if something is out of the ordinary!**    You are the eyes and ears of your organisation. You might notice if something is out of the ordinary, for example:    * People walking around without ID badges.  * Co-workers bypassing security measures.  * Unguarded keys.  * Confidential documents on desks.  * Passwords on sticky notes.  * Information on flip charts and whiteboards.
Will you make others aware of security measures, if they are unknowing?

**Become an ambassador of your organisation's security.**    You can help protect your organisation and your colleagues by becoming an ambassador of your organisation's security. There is a lot you can do, such as:    * Making other colleagues aware of the security measures.  * Helping test the effectiveness of measures.  * Proactively make the organisation aware of security issues.
You have almost completed this chapter. Please continue with the summary and start on your Insider Threat Awareness Certificate.
Say something and save the day!
Trust your instincts and speak up!
Get involved    Estimated learning time:  7 mintues
**You have completed this Insider Threat Awareness training!    You can exit this training by closing the tab in your window.**
